black mountain is a canadian band and
this is their third lp
wilderness heart long time viewers of
the channel may be familiar with this
group because here and there i've kind
of
peppered my videos with a lot of love
for their second lp in the future and
without getting into too much detail of
their repertoire i think you could
pretty much sum up this band by saying
they like to cherry pick
various forms of rock and roll from the
60s and 70s anything from psych to
garage to early metal if you're one of
these classic rock dudes this is
definitely a band that you must be
listening to wilderness heart is no less
into that blueprint coming off sounding
a little more complex than their first
album but kind of taking it back a
little bit on the
wankery the indulgences of their last lp
in the future you guys already know i

reason you were looking for these guys
to get a little more straightforward a

wish the solos here pretty contained the
structures are very straightforward
let's just say that there's very little
little fine print on this album and
there's an interesting dynamic going on
with this album too it's pretty black
and white really two sides to this album
and side number one acoustic folky lots
of lyrics about how modern society is
going to hell in a hand basket kind of
like the opening track to this lp the
hair song and then there are other
acoustic tracks that are much more quiet
much more eerie but maybe a little
forgettable and underwhelming at points
side number two to this album is the
rougher side the dirtier side the
distorted side chugging guitar riffs
heavy bass a very stoner rock sound but
i would say it's got kind of a sober
delivery if you get what i'm saying not
really any danger to these ladder tracks
which is sad because i like feeling that
when i hear a loud song there's little
to no
menace when these guys get
voluminous my main issue is that the

whereas with this type of music not just

to them not being so regulated i mean
really steppenwolf was more experimental
than this that's not a joke i was really
looking for black mountain to kind of
just get loose on this lp the first
moments where that feeling does kind of

little too late now i understand black
mountain doesn't want to repeat

there is a lot of attention on that part

the bass sounded really good the drums
are spot-on i just wish it sounded a
little more
wet and wild so i'm feeling like a
